trial_identification.studytitle: The effects of droperidol and olanzepine in addition to midazolam for sedating very agitated patients: a multi-centre, randomised, controlled clinical trial
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A randomised clinical trial to compare the efficacy of intravenous droperidol and olanzepine as adjuncts to midazolam for sedation of the severely agitated patient

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Conditions of unknown or disputed aetiology (such as chronic fatigue syndrome/myalgic encephalomyelitis)

interventions.interventions: Single intravenous bolus dose of 5mg droperidol (0.5mg/ml) or 5mg olanzapine (0.5mg/ml) immediately prior to sedation with intravenous midazolam
interventions.comparator: Single intravenous bolus of 10ml of normal saline (control)

primaryOutcome.outcome: Time to sedation as defined by a sedation score of less than or equal to 2 on a 6 point scale (6=highly agitated & violent, 0=asleep)
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Adequate sedation will be expected within 60 minutes of commencement of initial drug administration

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Need for re-sedation less than 60 minutes after sedation initially achieved
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: within 60 minutes of achieving adequate sedation initially

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Emergecncy department patients who require chemical sedation as determined by an Emergency Physician or a senior registrar.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: known hypersensitivity to midazolam, droperidol or olanzepine, reversible aetiology for agitation (hypotension, hypoxia, hypoglycaemia), known pregnancy, acute alcohol withdrawal.

trial_design.concealment: Patients requiring sedation will be determined by Emergency Physicians or Registrars. The next sequential study pack will be assigned to the patient. The study pack will contain the drugs randomly assigned to the patient. All drugs will be blinded.
trial_design.designfeatures: All people involved will be blinded. A double bummy approach will be employed.

fundingsource.fundingname: Australasian College for Emergency Medicine Research Foundation

ethicsAndSummary.summary: We believe that the addition of either 5mh of droperidol or 5mg olanzapine immediately prior to sedation with midazolam will result in safe and more effective sedation
ethicsAndSummary.publication: Chan EW, Taylor DMcD, Knott JC, Phillips GA, Castle DJ, Kong DCM. Intravenous droperidol or olanzapine as adjuncts to midazolam for the acutely agitated patient: A multi-centre, randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial - Reply. Annals Emerg Med 2013; 61: 598-599
